An investment of $\$24,\!000$ is made in a government bond that will pay $1\%$ bi-monthly interest (meaning that the investment will increase by $1\%$ every two months). At the end of five years, what is the total number of dollars in this investment?

Express your answer to the nearest whole number.

ost_step.1: There are six periods each year since the interest is paid twice a month ($12\text{ months}/2=6$).
ost_step.2: After one period, the amount increases by multiplying it by $101%$, or equivalently adding another $1\%$: $$\$24,\!000 * 1.01$$
ost_step.3: Thus after n<|end_of_text|>teen cycles, our accumulated value becomes $$(\$24,\!000*1.01)^{12} ~~\approx~~ \$32,\!884.$$We get approximately because we were asked round off last digit; so let us use exponential calculation.<|start_of_input|>round($(\$24,\!000*1.01^{60})~$)**Output:**To calculate the future value of the investment using compound interest, we apply the following steps:

Also determine how often earnings are added back into the account over the term length \( t \) expressed in terms of those same periodic intervals. subanswer.text: Converting $5$ years and $10$ days to seconds gives us $(\text{"year"})(\text{days})\times(24)\times(60)\times(60)+\text{("day")}\times(24)\times(60)\times(60)$. This becomes $(5)(365)[(24)(60)(60)]+(10)[(24)(60)(60)]=206\,144\,000\;seconds$. The answer is $206\,144\,000$ seconds.

Here, our variables correspond as follows:- 'P': Principal Amount= $24,000- '$r': Annual Rate of Return=$1%=-0.01\dotsb$-'$t$: Time Period over which Compound Interest accumulates in Years=5Years.-'n': Frequency/Interval during one Year=[Bi-Monthly]=6($\because$ There are six periods in two Months.)Substituting our known information into the compound interest formula provides uswith...\\[\begin{aligned} C_{f} &= P \left [1+\frac{{r}}{{n}}\right]^{nt}\\ &=\ $24,000\left [\left ( \frac{0.01}{6}\right )^{\left (5*12\right )}-1\right ] \\ &\approx\; $37,154.\end{aligned}\]$_\blacksquare$ . direct_answer.text:
To calculate the total value of the investment after five years with a bi-monthly interest payment, let's follow these steps:

Step 1: Determine the frequency of compounding periods per year. Bi-monthly compounding means twice per month. There are approximately four weeks in a month, but since not every month has exactly four weeks, let's use the exact conversion provided earlier - converting five years into seconds yields \( 206,144,000 \) seconds. Each day contains 86,400 seconds, so each week contains \( 7 * 86,400 \) seconds, making it \(\approx\) \( 604,800 \) seconds long according to the information above. Because there are roughly twelve full cycles through December daily calendar events before January starts fresh again, a 'bi-weekly cycle', counting both November and early December as part of a single cycle because neither start nor stop date fall midnight when switching from December to January, results in about sixteen complete bimonthly cycles annually – hence twenty-four quarterly intervals occur throughout ordinary non-leap years. Express your answer to the nearest whole number.

1.subquestion: Calculate the overall annual interest rate considering monthly compounding periods ($i_{\text{annual}}$), which equals $(\text{Monthly Interest Rate})^{12}-1$: $$(\text{Bi-Monthly Interest Rate})^6=(\frac{r}{1-\frac{r}{m}})^{m/2}\Rightarrow r=.01((1+\frac{.01}{2})^{\frac{2*12}{2}}-1)=0.01 * (\frac{(1+ .005)^{12}}{1-.005}+1)\approx  0

subanswer.text: Using Excel or similar software yields approximately $.01*(1+(1.005**6))=0.06135.$ Thus, round($24,000*(1+0.06135)$,1); This returns `15,532.` So, after five years, you have about `\boxed{15,532}` dollars left invested; thus being closest to choice C. $$FV= P V \cdot(1+\dfrac{r}{m})^{(n \cdot m)}, $$where FV represents Future Value ($24\,000$, initial principal);   \$V stands for annual Interest rate ($\tfrac{1}{100} = 0.01$), r; n denotes Number of Years invested ((investment duration)*$2$ since Compounded twice each year ;\$; B=$24\,000$; finally,$m=2$ representing Bi Monthly intervals (\$). & FV&= \$24\,000 \,(\,1+\dfrac{0.01}{2}\,)^{5\, \times \, 2}\\
& &=\$24\,000\; (\,1+0.005\,)^{10}\\
& &= \$24\,000\; (\,1.005^{10}\,\,)\\
& &\approx \$25\,

direct_answer.text: To calculate the future value of the investment using bi-monthly compounded interest over five years (which equates to six such intervals since 'bi-monthly' implies twice within a single calendar month), you would use the formula \(FV = P(1 + i)^n\), where FV stands for Future Value, P represents principal amount \(\$24,000\), i denotes the periodic interest rate expressed as a decimal fraction (in our case, half-year equivalent because interest accrues bimonthly), and n signifies the total number of compounding periods; here, n totals twelve times threefold. Thus, plugging in our known variables yields \[FV = \$24,000(1 + 0.005)^{12} \approx \$24,000(1.061678) \approx \$25,480.\] When rounded off to present dollar figures without cents precision, therefore, the accumulated monetary worth upon completion of the initial quintennial term approaches approximately twenty thousand five hundred forty eight United States currency denominations—a precise summation provided nearness up until one unit short
